discussion.content:
The images on here don't show the full "picture", pun intended.
Go here for a full version: https://cloudtech.how/comptia/cysa-cs0-001-q-001/

TRUE POSITIVE - ENCRYPT ENTIRE SESSION
The server seems to using HTTP. I would assume "Encrypt Entire Session" means "Enable SSL/TLS". Disabling HTTP would not automatically enable HTTPS.
FALSE POSITIVE - SUBMIT AS NON-ISSUE
The Secure flag has been set for the cookies. Cookies with the secure flag can only be sent over HTTPS.
TRUE POSITIVE - REQUEST CERTIFICATE FROM A PUBLIC CA
This looks like a self-signed certificate, so requesting an actual certificate from a public CA seems like the most logical answer.

What do you guys think?

WS1 - True Positive (Encrypt Entire Session)
WS2 - False Positive (Submit as non-issue)
WS3 - True Positive (Request certificate from a public CA)
Agreed
why is the scan report here filled with typos?
This question was on the exam (october-2020)
"SET SECURE ATTRIBUTE WHEN COOKIE SHOULD SENT VIA HTTPS ONLY" is not listed as an option - is this the same as disable http? if so, is it then a fllse negative?
This was on the exam.

comments.content: This was indeed in the exam :)

discussion.content:
The correct answer: 

WEBSERVER01 - TRUE POSITVE - ENCRYPT ENTIRE SESSION
WEBSERVER02 - FALSE POSITIVE - SUBMIT AS NON ISSUE
WEBSERVER03 - TRUE POSITVE - REQUEST CERTIFICATE FROM A PUBLIC CA
Can anyone put the 'solutions' provided. Like would enable ssl/tls be 'encrypting the whole session'? Or would it be turning off http?

comments.content:
Web server 01 - True Positive - Encrypt Entire Session
Web server 02 - True Positive - Encrypt All Session Cookies
Web server 03 - True Positive - Request Certificate from a Public CA
Not sure about the disable http part in web server 02 though.
why is 2 a true positive? In the logs, don't all have the cookies have the secure attribute checked?

discussion.content: This is wrong server 2 is a false positive.

comments.content: please how do you know the 'x' means the secure attribute has been set?
Isn't it correct? The secure field has "x" meaning the cookie should only be sent on a secure connection.

questions.answer_description:
WEB_SERVER01: VALID "" IMPLEMENT SSL/TLS
WEB_SERVER02: VALID "" SET SECURE ATTRIBUTE WHEN COOKIE SHOULD SENT VIA HTTPS ONLY
WEB_SERVER03: VALID "" IMPLEMENT CA SIGNED CERTIFICATE

questions.question_text:
A security analyst received a compromised workstation. The workstation's hard drive may contain evidence of criminal activities. Which of the following is the
FIRST thing the analyst must do to ensure the integrity of the hard drive while performing the analysis?

discussion.content: This question was in the exam :)
Blocker for keep data to change

comments.content:
The answer is A 
A Write Blocker: ensures hard drives being imaged cannot be written to or its data changed.
It ensures integrity of the captured disk
I meant the answer is B
The question states "while performing analysis". I would assume that you make a copy before you perform an analysis.

discussion.content:
A - <--- why wouldn't this be the FIRST thing?
B - A write blocker is any tool that permits read-only access to data storage devices without compromising the integrity of the data.
C - rm -r deletes the target directory and recursively deletes everything inside that directory
D - ??

choices.D: Install it on a different machine and explore the content.
choices.C: Run rm ""R command to create a hash.
choices.A: Make a copy of the hard drive.

questions.question_text: Considering confidentiality and integrity, which of the following make servers more secure than desktops? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
OS- server operating systems
Trained Operators- Server administrators as against normal users
Physical access restriction- Based on their importance and criticality to the business, other physical controls may be implemented to restrict access to only authorized personnel

comments.content:
I disagree with VLAN as desktops could also operate in specified VLANs i.e. Accountant Dept and HR Dept could be in separate VLANs. 

Server OS are usually more hardened than Desktop OS.

discussion.content: Should OS be part of this option. It doesn't seem like it. U can run the same OS on a system and a server, so that shouldn't be an answer. I had go for VLAN instead.

choices.A: The analyst is attempting to measure bandwidth utilization on interface eth0.
choices.D: The analyst is attempting to capture traffic for a PCAP file.
choices.E: The analyst is attempting to use a protocol analyzer to monitor network traffic.
choices.B: The analyst is attempting to capture traffic on interface eth0.
choices.C: The analyst is attempting to replay captured data from a PCAP file.

discussion.content: file2cable is not a protocol analyzer but a tool used to send a file as raw frames. So, nearest answer should be C - replay captured data from the PCAP file

I think the answer is C. According the man page, file2cable sends a file as ethernet frames. The switch i is for interface. Switch f is for file. So the command file2cable i eth0 file.pcap means run file.pcap on interface eth0.
BEST describes... C is specific but the question is 'What is the person wanting to do...' Ergo E... imo

The correct answer is C

Source: http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/xenial/man1/file2cable.1.html
I concur with lupinart and s3curity1

questions.question_text:
Given the following output from a Linux machine:
file2cable ""i eth0 -f file.pcap
Which of the following BEST describes what a security analyst is trying to accomplish?
Various devices are connecting and authenticating to a single evil twin within the network. Which of the following are MOST likely being targeted?

discussion.content: Can anyone explain. Why re dey so sure that it just mobile phones the attacker is after. What about all endpoint.

comments.content: End points could be desktops also, but the catch of the question is evil twin, which is a type of wi-fi attack, which obviously will not affect an endpoint connected physically to the network over an ethernet cable, mobile devices seems to be the only end point that can be affected by evil twin attack

Laptop falls under Mobile devices (Mobile Computer). 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_device

The reason why the answer is "A" is because mobile device can only connect wirelessly to the network. For example: Your organization setup a wireless network with the SSID - ABC123, an attack can mimic a wireless network with SSID like ABCI23 (evil twin) to trick the user into connecting.

Where else for option "B" (All end points) can be referred to many things such as Desktop, Workstation and etc. In an organization setting, desktops, workstations are normally connected through the RJ45 port.
